title: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
scope: ** Evaluation, diagnosis, treatment initiation, and long-term management of CIDP in adults. Covers typical CIDP, CIDP variants (MADSAM, DADS, sensory CIDP), first-line immunotherapy (IVIg, corticosteroids, plasmapheresis), second-line immunosuppressants, and subcutaneous immunoglobulin therapy. Primary focus is outpatient management with coverage for acute presentations and hospitalizations. Excludes Guillain-Barré syndrome (acute onset <8 weeks), hereditary neuropathies (CMT), and pediatric CIDP.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, treatment initiation, and long-term management planning
Neuromuscular specialist referral for diagnostic uncertainty, treatment-refractory cases, or consideration of advanced therapies
Infusion center referral for ongoing IVIg administration and monitoring
Home infusion service referral for SCIg training and home therapy setup
Physical therapy for gait training, fall prevention, strengthening exercises, and mobility optimization
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive equipment, and energy conservation strategies
Pain management consult for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to gabapentin/pregabalin/duloxetine
Endocrinology consult for steroid-induced diabetes management or osteoporosis prevention
Hematology consult if monoclonal protein detected for POEMS or myeloma workup
Pulmonology consult if respiratory symptoms develop (rare in CIDP; consider GBS overlap)
Rheumatology consult if connective tissue disease suspected based on labs or clinical features
Social work for disability resources, transportation assistance, and community support services
PCP follow-up for chronic disease management, steroid side effect monitoring, and preventive care

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if progressive weakness, difficulty walking, or breathing problems develop (may indicate disease progression or acute worsening)
Keep all IVIg/infusion appointments as scheduled to maintain disease control and prevent relapses
Do not stop immunosuppressive medications suddenly as this may cause disease flare; taper only under physician guidance
Report signs of infection (fever, cough, dysuria) promptly as immunosuppression increases infection risk
Use fall precautions including handrails, non-slip surfaces, and assistive devices due to balance and weakness
Perform home exercises as prescribed by physical therapy to maintain strength and flexibility
Monitor for IVIg side effects including headache, fever, chills, or rash during infusions; report severe symptoms
Keep a symptom diary tracking strength, numbness, and functional abilities to share at follow-up visits
Carry a medical ID card indicating CIDP diagnosis and current treatments in case of emergency
Contact GBS-CIDP Foundation (www.gbs-cidp.org) for patient education, support groups, and resources

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) to prevent worsening of neuropathy if diabetic
Limit alcohol consumption as alcohol worsens peripheral neuropathy and interacts with medications
Ensure adequate vitamin B12 and folate intake through diet or supplementation to support nerve health
Avoid smoking as it impairs circulation and may worsen neuropathy
Stay up to date on vaccinations (flu, pneumonia, COVID-19, shingles) but avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppression
Wear protective footwear to prevent injury to numb feet and avoid burns or trauma
Perform daily foot inspections for wounds or ulcers given sensory loss
Engage in low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary cycling, walking) to maintain cardiovascular health and strength
Maintain bone health with calcium, vitamin D, and weight-bearing exercise, especially if on steroids
Manage stress and get adequate sleep as fatigue worsens CIDP symptoms
